Award.AwardTitle: Archetypes and Prototypes of Decisions under Uncertainty

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project uses a series of decision making experiments to gather data for understanding choice under uncertainty. The project also develops tools for the theoretical analysis of choice under uncertainty and a blend of parametric and non-parametric econometric techniques for testing the theory with the new data. The theoretical and experimental aspects of the project provide a richer understanding of risk preferences and the choices that implement them.

The experiments provide a positive account of choice under uncertainty in an environment that allows for a general characterization of the patterns of individual behavior. Previous data show that although there is considerable heterogeneity in choce behavior, participants do behave in a way that is consistent in the sense that choices maximize a consistent set of preferences. However, subjects also use identifiable common heuristics (rules of thumb) to make decisions. These two different kinds of behavior reflect two different kinds of rationality: substantive rationality and procedural rationality. The new theory combines these two different ideas into a single model and the research team will use the new theory to develop a method to identify when people make decisions using procedural or substantive rationality.

Understanding how people make decisions in risky situations is an important and interdisciplinary research question that also has important implications for public policy. The experimental platform and the analytical techniques that the researchers are developing will be broadly useful to the research community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project we generated and analyzed data for understanding individual choice, especially under uncertainty, in experiments in the laboratory and in the field. The experiments provide a positive account of individual decision making in a choice environment that allows for a general characterization of the patterns of individual behavior. Experimental subjects saw on a computer screen a geometrical representation of a choice problem involving two or three assets. Subjects chose an allocation through a simple point-and-click design. This intuitive and user-friendly interface allows for the quick and efficient elicitation of many decisions per subject under a wide range of choice scenarios.

In addition to experimental methods, we have also developed theoretical tools and econometric techniques for the analysis of individual choice in the laboratory. This combination of theoretical and experimental tools provides a better understanding of individual preferences and behavior. The work had made substantive contributions to the study of individual heterogeneity and bounded rationality and has also contributed to experimental methodology. The entire apparatus --- theory, experimental methodology, and econometrics for linking theory to data --- has provided useful tools for a range of disciplines interested in individual choice.

More specifically, this NSF support has facilitated a series of papers on choice under uncertainty. We extended earlier experimental work in settings with risk (known probabilities) to settings with ambiguity (unknown probabilities). Our subjects solved a series of portfolio-choice problems. The assets were Arrow securities corresponding to three states of nature, where the probability of one state is known and the remaining two are ambiguous. The experiment enabled us to estimate parametric models of ambiguity aversion at the level of the individual subject. The sample exhibits considerable heterogeneity in preferences, as captured by parameter estimates. Nonetheless, there exists a strong tendency to equalize the demands for the securities that pay off in the ambiguous states, indicating ambiguity aversion. We also find that a large number of subjects are well described by the ambiguity-neutral Savage's (1954) celebrated theory of Subjective Expected Utility.

In work with the CentERpanel (a representative sample of more than 2,000 Dutch households) we investigated the correlation between individual behavior and demographic and economic characteristics. The most striking result of this work is that consistency with utility maximization in the experiment is strongly related to wealth: a standard deviation increase in the consistency score is associated with 15-19 percent more wealth. The results condition on socioeconomic variables including current income, education, and family structure, and is little changed when we add controls for past income, risk tolerance and the results of a standard personality test used by psychologists. These findings are particularly notable given the substantial heterogeneity in our experimental outcomes, and the brief experimental exposure.

The sponsored research also led to a series of papers which employ a similar methodology to study social preferences. The experiment used modified dictator games that varied the price of giving -- the amount by which one?s own payoff must be decreased to increase the payoff to another subject. The experimental design allows us to decompose subjects? preferences into two distinct tradeoffs:  the tradeoff between self and other (fair-mindedness versus self-interest) and the tradeoff between equality and efficiency. In experiments with law students and medical students we found that these samples are substantially more efficiency-focused than the general population. We also demonstrated the predictive validity of our experimental measure by showing that it predicts the subsequent career choices of the students. Our findings indicate sharp differences in social preferences between subjects of varying degrees of ?eliteness.? These results provide a starting point for future research on the distinct preferences of the elite and differences in social preferences across groups more generally.

Risk and social preferences are important inputs into broader measures of welfare and enter many realms of individual decision-making. This research's fundamental contributions to understanding these personal and social preferences therefore had broad-reaching implications in many disciplines, ranging from economics, through philosophy, and into law.. Further, the experimental platform and analytical techniques that have been developed and were refined through this project were also used by other researchers. All experiments and programs for analysis were made publicly available through the web.

Research assistants with training in theory, econometrics and experimental economics were engaged by the PI and worked collaboratively with the Ps and with one another. Graduate students were also be involved in the research indirectly as participants in workshops and graduate courses, where the results and methods will be taught and discussed. Colleagues from economics, philosophy, law, and related disciplines commented on the results and analysis of completed experiments and the design of ongoing and future experiments. Every effort was be made to encourage the most diverse participation possible in the public activities associated with this project.
